titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Papers of Abby Weed Grey
1922-1978
MC.151
titlestmt.author: Amy Surak. Additional processing by Aleksandr Gelfand.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from grey02KS.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-03-10 09:13:42 -0500.

change.item: Container list and extent updated by John Zarrillo
Updated by Kelly Haydon to reflect the addition of accessible film scans
Updated by Lyric Evans-Hunter to reflect digitization of video materials

physdesc.extent: in 32 manuscript boxes, 6 flat boxes, and 5 record cartons.

did.abstract: The Abby Weed Grey Papers span the years 1922-1978, with the bulk of the material covering the period 1960-1974. The papers document Mrs. Grey's world travels, published and unpublished works, and her collection and curation of art.
did.langmaterial: Materials in the collection are primarily in English, with some publications in other languages.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in series and subseries determined before the collection arrived at the University Archives.
The series and subseries arrangement of the collection is as follows:

list.item: Grey Gallery and Study Center NYU

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the New York University Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Portrait and Biographical Files in the New York University Archives
New York University Photograph Collection, NYU Buildings, Grey Gallery and Study Center
"Abby Weed Grey," page from the Grey Art Gallery web site: http://www.nyu.edu/greyart/information/Abby_Weed_Grey/body_abby_weed_grey.html

The following reference materials: Grey, Abby Weed. The Picture is the Window, The Window is the Picture: An Autobiographical Journey. New York: New York University Press, 1983. One World Through Art: A Selection of 1001 Works of Art from the Ben and Abby Grey Foundation. St. Paul, Minn.: Ben and Abby Grey Foundation, 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Abby Weed Grey Papers span the years 1922-1978, with the bulk of the material covering the period 1960-1974. These papers illustrate Mrs. Grey's world travels and her interest in art. Documentation is most extensive pertaining to the writing of her autobiography entitled "The Picture is the Window, The Window is the Picture: An Autobiographical Journey". They also provide information on the Iranian artist-sculptor Parviz Tanavoli and Mrs. Grey's gift to New York University to fund the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center. The collection also contains some material related to her earlier life.

Materials in Series I - XV include published and unpublished materials of Abby Weed Grey's writing; information on international artists; correspondence between Grey and artists, in particular Parviz Tanavoli; catalogs, publicity and clippings pertaining to exhibitions; and scrapbooks and oversized materials. Materials in Series XVI include magnetic audio tapes and film reels of varying sizes. Materials in Series XVII include photos of works of art in her collection and exhibitions, personal photos, and snapshots taken traveling abroad.
The contents of each series and subseries are described in more detail in the series-level scope and content notes.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of the original materials, digital surrogates must be used when viewing the audiovisual materials in the collection.

bioghist.head: Biography of Abby Weed Grey
bioghist.p: Abby Weed Grey, the oldest of four children, was born on October 23, 1902, to Paul Charles Weed and Emily Weed in St. Paul, Minnesota. She grew up in St. Paul, attending both elementary and high school there. In 1920, Abby headed off east where she attended Vassar College, a private all women's college in Poughkeepsie, New York. After graduating in 1924, Abby spent the next few years (what she considered her "wander years") traveling abroad with a college roommate to Riga, Latvia, and Paris, France. Following her return from Paris in 1926, Abby started teaching fifth grade in a private school for girls in Kansas City. It was at this time that she met Lieutenant Colonel Benjamin Edwards Grey. In 1928 she became engaged and a year later married Benjamin Grey, 20 years her senior. For the next 27 years she lived as an Army wife, traveling on cross-country trips and entertaining. During that time, her husband invested in Western railroad stocks and bonds. In 1947 they purchased their first home, the family cabin in Deer Lake, Minnesota. They moved between Minnesota and Salt Lake City, Utah. In 1956 Ben died of cancer in St. Paul, Minnesota.

After Ben's death, Abby moved back to St. Paul, Minnesota. Before leaving she established the annual Benjamin Edwards Grey Memorial Lecture in poetry as part of the Summer Writers' Conference at the University of Utah.

In 1960, after being widowed for four years, Abby Grey took her first trip around the world with a group of thirteen women to Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand, Cambodia, India, Kashmir, Nepal, Pakistan, Iran, and Israel. In these foreign countries, some nearly totally unaware of Western influence, Mrs. Grey began her search for an innovative artist by meeting with working with local artists and collecting contemporary art to be shown in America.

One year later Mrs. Grey established The Ben & Abby Grey Foundation, Inc., founded for the encouragement of art through the assembling of international collections of art for cultural exchange programs. Also in 1961 she founded the "Minnesota Art Portfolio" exhibit (MAP) as an opportunity for artists to see original works by their Western counterparts. She met with Malcolm Lein, the director of the St. Paul Art Center, and selected Minnesota artists' works to bring on a trip to Spain, Greece, Italy, Turkey, and Iran. Through the United States Information Service (USIS) and the People-to-People Program, the exhibit traveled throughout the Middle East and the Mediterranean for two years. During her trip to Iran with MAP, Abby met Bishop Hassan Dehqani-Tafti of St. Luke's Church while attending Anglican services.

One artist in whom Mrs. Grey took particular interest was Iranian artist-sculptor Parviz Tanavoli, whom she met in 1961. The following year the Grey Foundation provided him a grant for six months as a visiting artist at the Minneapolis School of Art. He remained as a sculptor/instructor on staff for the following two years. In June 1964 Tanavoli returned to Iran with the gift of a bronze foundry for the University of Tehran given by the Grey Foundation.

Throughout the rest of the 1960s and early 1970s Mrs. Grey initiated many projects. These included "Fourteen Contemporary Iranians" (1962-65), which toured American cities, as did "Turkish Art Today" (1966-70), which also traveled to Tehran, Iran. Communication through Art, comprised of three exhibitions of American work, opened simultaneously in 1964 in Istanbul, Tehran, and Lahore and traveled for five years in the eastern Mediterranean, Asia, and eastern Africa. This program, which complemented the goals of USIS, was accompanied by books and catalogues representing the American art scene. Mrs. Grey also sponsored the American section of the India Triennial of Contemporary World Art in 1968. Two years later she co-sponsored it with New York's Museum of Modern Art. In 1972, "One World Through Art," an exhibition of 1,001 works from Mrs. Grey's collection, was shown at the Minnesota State Fair Grounds.

As Mrs. Grey's collection grew, she sought a place to exhibit her collection and share it with other people. At first, Mrs. Grey looked for a home for her art in her own locality. The University of Minnesota was ruled out because the gallery space available was inconvenient and the school administrators would have run the gallery. Mrs. Grey also looked at her alma mater, Vassar College, but finally chose New York University, because it gave her the flexibility that she wanted. Also, since her collection was a unique, New York City seemed the ideal place to house it. The Ben and Abby Grey Foundation, founded for the encouragement of art, donated one million dollars to NYU and in the spring of 1975, the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center was completed.

Four years later, Mrs. Grey again donated money to NYU for an art history study center that was built on the third floor of main building. In addition to the Gallery and Study Center, Mrs. Grey provided the funds to renovate the NYU undergraduate art history classrooms, auditorium and faculty offices.

By 1979, Abby Grey had become one of the foremost collectors of Asian and Middle Eastern art. She had made nine trips to Asia and had collected over 600 artworks from native artists in Egypt, Greece, Iran, India, Japan, Turkey, Pakistan, and her hometown of St. Paul, Minnesota.
On June 2, 1983, Abby Weed Grey died of cancer in St. Paul at the age of 80 years.

Throughout her life, as a patron to the arts, Mrs. Grey served on The Minnesota Society of Fine Arts (the governing body of the Minnesota Institute of Arts) Board of Trustees from 1967-73 and on the Minneapolis College of Art and Design's Board of Overseers from 1964 until her death. She established Abby Weed Grey scholarships at the College as well. At the Walker Art Center she endowed the Grey Fellowship in Museum Studies. At Hamline University she helped sponsor symposia in Near Eastern Studies and has been a benefactor to St. Catherine's College and the St. Paul Academy-Summit School. She was a member of The Women's Club of Minneapolis and The Cosmopolitan Club of New York.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Abby Weed Grey Papers; MC 151; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: There may be some restrictions on the use of the collection. For more information, contact: New York University Archives, Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The paper and photographic materials in this collection are open for use without restrictions. The collection also contains audiovisual materials that have not been digitized. Please contact the University Archives if you wish to access these materials.

custodhist.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
custodhist.p: The papers of Abby Weed Grey were transferred from the Grey Study Center Library of New York University to the University Archives in the Spring of 1998.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Further processing of the Abby Weed Grey Papers was conducted in January-May 2016 for preservation purposes. The papers in the collection were shifted from letter size folders stored in Paige cartons to legal size folders stored in manuscript boxes. Audiovisual materials not previously inspected and rehoused by Preservation also received that treatment. All of this work resulted in a renumbering of the boxes and folders in the collection. However, the collection's existing arrangement was preserved, except in the case of notes originally housed with audiovisual recordings, which were moved to Box 28.

Some metadata cleanup was also conducted during this process. Misspellings were corrected, audiovisual format information was supplied or updated, and information regarding the dates of materials was supplied where available. Date information was also reconfigured to reflect DACS 2.0 requirements.
Additional metadata cleanup was conducted in November 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains edited drafts of Abby Weed Grey's book, published in 1983, The Picture is the Window, The Window is the Picture. They are arranged in page order and chronological order beginning with her "early years" pages 1-39. The dates included in the manuscript begin in 1902 (her birth) with earlier dates for family history. Last date on copy is 1979. Also included are notes on the organization of the book and notes on writing a book.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence about the draft of her book. These letters include notes for the book, the outline and structure of the book, and edited pages of book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains 7 poetry notebooks, 2 poetry small binders, 1 black binder with notes, pictures, short stories, and articles. One black binder, a scrapbook, has been separated and moved to Box 8. These notebooks and binders consist of writings about her life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contain spiral and unbound notebooks and copies of notebooks arranged chronologically by date. These consist of notes, poetry, journal entries, essays, descriptions of travel, and information regarding artists, MAP, USIA, and Parviz Tanavoli (see biographical description).

scopecontent.p: Contains diaries of travels (originals, edited, and copies), poems, and a photo essay/diary which has been separated and removed to Box 8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains information regarding international artists, including correspondence, published materials regarding their work, clippings, artist profiles, pamphlets. Materials are arranged alphabetically by subject/country, with most in English, although some in other languages including French and languages of the country represented. It is divided into six subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains general information on artists AWG associated with including a catalog, correspondence and index cards with information on specific artists mentioned in her diaries.

scopecontent.p: All materials are in regards to the 1973 proposal of establishing the Grey museum at the University of Minnesota. These materials include professional and personal correspondence, architectural plans, and meeting minutes of the Grey Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials are arranged in chronological order. Materials include personal and professional correspondence, clippings, film narrations, invitations, invoices, meeting minutes, and progress reports. The bulk are from 1967.

scopecontent.p: Materials in this series are arranged chronologically. Materials include professional and personal correspondence, invitations, clippings, catalogs (in English and other languages), scrapbooks (separated and located in Box 8), financial information, invoices, photographs (separated and located in Photo Collection), itineraries, reports, and notes.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some audiovisual materials may be restricted. For more information, please contact the University Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This multimedia collection has been separated out into 4 boxes (3 paige boxes and one large archival box - approximately 5 feet of material). The collection consists of reel to reel tapes of 3", 5", 7", and larger sizes and cassette tapes. The reel to reel tapes of sizes 7" and smaller have been removed from their original non-archival boxes and re-housed in acid free boxes and sleeves. They have been labeled according to the information provided on their original boxes. In some instances more in-depth information regarding the content of the materials are included with the reels and tapes. No material has been separated.

physdesc.physfacet: Original Label on container: TV Anchor Channel 2; The first 10 minutes of audio cut between broadcast recordings of art auction results and Abby Weed Grey giving information on the broadcasts (dates, networks, locations, etc.); This is followed by 22 minutes of Grey reading poetry; audio quality is poor due to low volume at recording; audio is audible only in the left channel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first portion is a recording of the St. Paul Minneapolis TV's educational station 2 program. The announcer is discussing six works of art that were donated by the Abby and Ben Grey Foundation. The artwork was part of the Young American Artists group, chosen from the students and faculty at the Minneapolis School of Art and Design. Abby Weed Grey speaks after to explain what TV show this had come from and that it aired on June 5, 1975 at 6:40 pm. The paintings from the Grey Foundation totaled $950. The second portion of this recording is Abby Weed Grey reading poetry. The audio is hard to hear and only comes out of one headphone.

did.unittitle: Mrs. Grey and Director of Fine Arts from the Smithsonian

physdesc.physfacet: Audio quality is good but magnetic hum is audible as is traffic driving around outside where it was being recorded; First minute of audio appears to be Smithsonian director testing microphones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The director of the Fine Arts Collection at the Smithsonian Institution is discussing a new show for India. A woman begins to speak on this show and explains how it was the first time contemporary American Art was in India. Abby Weed Grey is the last to speak and comments on the terrific response to the show in India.

physdesc.physfacet: Recording begins at 2:48; Audio speed is slow and irregular but eventually speeds up to normal. All recordings on this tape may be identified by Unique Identifiers beginning with MC151_ref1463.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Abby Weed Grey is practicing a talk that she will be giving to the St. Louis Park Women's Club on January 5, 1964. Grey is using slides of places that she has been to and of artwork from artists that she has befriended to show how artists are coping with the modern age.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals Note
originalsloc.p: Original cassette tape located in box 12

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Track 1 Abby Weed Grey is recording herself. She is describing what art means to her and recalls her earliest experiences in art collecting. She reiterates the idea that art can be a form of communication. This recording is easy to hear.

Track 2 Abby Weed Grey is reading entries from her diary. She begins in 1961 in Isfahan, Persia in which she recalls her time spent there. The recording ends with her reading entries from the later 1960s when she is back in the United States. This recording is easy to hear

Series XVII: Abby Weed Grey Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The photographs are housed in 3 manuscript boxes and 2 flat boxes. Inclusive dates are 1962-1982, although the bulk consists of photos from 1965-68.
